Dataset-LongName: OSTM/JASON-2 GEOPHYSICAL DATA RECORD SEA SURFACE HEIGHT ANOMALIES VERSION D
Dataset-LongName-Full: OSTM/JASON-2 GEOPHYSICAL DATA RECORD SEA SURFACE HEIGHT ANOMALIES VERSION D
Dataset-Description: The Geophysical Data Records (GDR) Sea Sufrace Height Anomaly (SSHA) files from the Ocean Surface Topography Mission (OSTM)/Jason-2 contain full accuracy altimeter data and SSHA, with a high precision orbit (accuracy 1.5 cm), provided approximately 35 days after data collection. The instruments on OSTM make direct observations of the following quantities: altimeter range, significant wave height, ocean radar backscatter cross-section (a measure of wind speed), ionospheric electron content (derived by a simple formula), tropospheric water content, mean sea surface, Sea Surface Height Anomalies (SSHA), and position relative to the GPS satellite constellation.  These data contain less parameters than the regular GDR data.  These data are distributed by NOAA NODC (National Ocean Data Center).
Dataset-Reference: OSTM/Jason-2 Products Handbook, CNES : SALP-MU-M-OP-15815-CN, EUMETSAT : EUM/OPS-JAS/MAN/08/0041, JPL : OSTM-29-1237, NOAA/NESDIS : Polar Series/OSTM J400
DatasetCitation-CitationDetail: OSTM/JASON-2 GEOPHYSICAL DATA RECORD SEA SURFACE HEIGHT ANOMALIES VERSION D
DatasetContact-Contact-Provider-LongName: Physical Oceanography Distributed Active Archive Center, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, NASA

DatasetSource-Source-Description: OSTM, the TOPEX/Poseidon and Jason-2 follow-on, is an oceanographic mission to study global ocean circulation, improve climate predictions and monitor events such as El Nino conditions.  It is a joint mission between CNES, NASA, NOAA and EUMETSAT.

OSTM, the TOPEX/Poseidon and Jason-2 follow-on, is an oceanographic mission to study global ocean circulation, improve climate predictions and monitor events such as El Nino conditions.  It is a joint mission between CNES, NASA, NOAA and EUMETSAT.

OSTM, the TOPEX/Poseidon and Jason-2 follow-on, is an oceanographic mission to study global ocean circulation, improve climate predictions and monitor events such as El Nino conditions.  It is a joint mission between CNES, NASA, NOAA and EUMETSAT.
DatasetSource-Sensor-Description: The TRSR isa an advanced codeless sixteen-channel Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver developed bye the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL). The on-board package is comprised of dual redunedant TRSR units and choke ring antennae. The GPS data are intended to provide supplementary positioning data in support of the POD function and/or to improve gravity field models.

The Poseidon-3 altimeter, operating at 13.575 GHz (Ku band) and 5.3 GHz (C band), is the primary sensor for the OSTM mission.  The measurements made at the two frequencies are combined to obtain measurements of the altimeter range, wind speed, significant wave height, and the ionoshperic correction.  The Poseidon-3 package consists of dual redundant altimeter units each of which has low mass and low power consumption.
DatasetVersion-Description: Creation of Dataset via Metadata Tool.
